###Question: Is it possible to lose eyesight and it mean nothing? 22F, 5Ûª6Û,207lbs, caucausian. One time event. Vape and smoke weed. I work in electrical so considered the possibility of damage from dust. History of bulimia which is currently active (would say 3-4 days are purge days). It comes down to last night, on a walk, I got excessively dizzy and weak. I kept on walking with vision in both eyes intermittently disappearing (never both eyes at once) eventually when the weakness peaked (it felt hard to identify words at this point, was on phone call) my left eye lost all vision for about 30 seconds. Afterwards the extreme blur stayed for about two hours. Had a big olÛª headache behind the left eye about an hour after vision loss. Still do, pulsing, changing in intensity at random. IÛªm hoping itÛªs nothing worrisome and really want to know if it is possible that is so. I canÛªt afford a copay til weeks end

And here is the original response that needs to be more empathetic:

###Answer: Neurosurgeon here.We use an unnecessarily fancy term for that: amaurosis fugax which means transient vision loss. It results from the retina not getting enough blood flow for a short period of time (the ophthalmic artery is the first to branch from the internal carotid artery and also has collateral flow from the external carotid in some people) and can be considered a stroke symptom, making it a TIA (transient ischemic attack: basically pre-stroke). Though since you're young, I wouldn't put a stenotic ICA or CCA on the top of my list as the "sudden, short and quickly recovered loss of vision" is more commonly a result of your blood pressure being too low for a short period of time. In other words your heart couldn't keep up to your brains oxygen (blood flow) needs for a short while but eventually adjusted, just a little bit late. If the symptom repeats, I would (if I were to see you as a patient in clinic or maybe the ER) refer you to a cardiologist and maybe also consider a brain vessel imaging (a CTA or MRA, whichever is preferred). Considering your history, dehydration may have exacerbated the issue so try to stay hydrated. A syncope event itself is mostly okay as blood flow to the brain is usually immediately recovered but falling down and hitting your head on something like concrete may not.<end_of_turn>

###Question: Pregnancy: Abnormal 12 Weeks Ultrasound My (34 F) doctor just called me to inform me about a prenatal ultrasound I had done 2 days ago.I'm currently 12 weeks, I already had another ultrasound at 8 weeks and everything seemed normal. No issues with the pregnancy so far either.This additional ultrasound was performed because my doctor told me this pregnancy is considered a "geriatric pregnancy".The technician kept switching the transducer (?) and tried to get the baby to move more to be able to take better pictures. ("The baby is not cooperative" was what she said.)Baby was moving and normal heartbeat was measured. Technician printed pictures for me and congratulated me on the pregnancy.When my OBGYN called today he told me that unfortunately something seems to be wrong with the baby, and asked if I already heard anything from the technician who did the ultrasound (I told him I did not).He couldn't tell me what medical condition it was, he said that he had never seen this before, the only thing he could tell me was that we need another ultrasound next week to confirm, and that genetic specialists might have to talk to me.He said that there might have been something wrong with the ultrasound machine, but he sounded so negative on the phone that it made me feel like this pregnancy won't be able to continue. When I asked him to be more specific, he mentioned the following- Cavum Septum Pellucidum (CSP) not seen- Nasal Bone absent- Brain is normal size but couldn't see a cerebellumI googled the CSP and found sites that mentioned it would be difficult to locate before 18 weeks.I'm devastated right now and find it difficult being left with this information and having to wait for another week, that's why I'm seeking for advise here.How likely is it that the technician just did a bad job or the ultrasound was not clear enough at 12 weeks, especially considering that so many features seem to be absent on the ultrasound? If the features are absent on the next ultrasound, what genetic disorder does this indicate and should I come to terms with the fact that this pregnancy most likely has to be terminated?Anything experienced something similar before? Ultrasound image Thank you for your help.Edit: Thank you for all your input so far.I have asked for the report and it was sent to me.These are the things mentioned as abnormal:"Choroid/skull: Abnormal. Head has a rounded appearance. Chloroid plexus appears abnormal. No cerebellum seen. Cavum septum pellucidum not identified.Abdominal wall/cord insertion: Abnormal. Omphalocele likely containing bowel just to the left of the cord insertion. Overall size measures approximately 8mm. There appears to be incomplete separation of the hemispheres with an apparent cortical defect."Everything else is listed as normal and nasal bone mentioned as identified; but then at the bottom of the report it sums up:"Impression:Single live fetus at 11 weeks 6 days.Abnormal appearance head, cerebrum and cerebellum.Absent nasal bone. Omphalocele."

And here is the original response that needs to be more empathetic:

###Answer: The ultrasound that is performed around 11-13 weeks of pregnancy is very important in order to detect certain abnormalities that can be seen early in pregnancy. The one image you have provided does not help a lot. However, absent nasal septum can be a worrying sign, although not always indicative of an actual problem with the fetus since it can be seen later in pregnancy. I have seen mothers with small noses have fetuses that looked like that on ultrasound but were born completely normal. Regarding the brain abnormalities, some cannot be seen clearly so early in pregnancy and some can be corrected later on. If absence of cerebellum is confirmed however, it can turn out to be a very serious condition for the newborn and can lead to severe developmental delay and neurological problems later in life. You should for sure have another ultrasound by a specialist in that field. You might need also further testing, e.g. amniocentesis to confirm. I don't want to sound extremely alarming but you should also think about the possibility of terminating such a pregnancy if severe abnormalities are confirmed. Excuse the maybe not so great use of the language but English is not my native language. If you need more clarification feel free to ask. Best of luck to you.<end_of_turn>

My blood pressure wasn't "High for my age" until around 18 (Despite how I was never put on meds for it until now).I feel like maybe I'm being over paranoid, but I match too many of these symptoms. Pale legs, easily cold feet, as a side note laying down in certain ways makes the top of one of my legs go numb now. ###Answer: Hi OP. I'm sorry you're going through this, must be difficult.&#x200B;Could it be coarctation of the aorta? Maybe. I can't know without examining you thoroughly and without an ankle brachial index (BP comparison between ankle and bicep.) You would also need an echocardiogram to confirm it.&#x200B;Let me answer the other question about the life expectancy. There is something you need to understand about life expectancy: It is a statistical figure.YOU are not a statistic. You are a real person with a real body that may or may not be similar to others. I prefer to tailor the discussion to the patient. From what you've said so far, it seems you have been mostly asymptomatic. I assure you though, you will not drop dead suddenly just because you have coarctation of the aorta, it usually leads to complications which you will definitely notice. ###Question: I'm a mom of 4 kids (ages 12, 11, 6, and 4). They're all fully vaccinated and always up-to-date on regular check-ups. My 6-year-old, who I'll call J, is the only kiddo with any issues, and they've generally been mild. Yesterday I noticed he has swollen, bleeding gums and a few ulcer-like sores in the back of his throat which the doctor diagnosed as hand, foot, and mouth disease (no tests were done though). Today I brought him back in due to his fever spiking to 104.6 and him struggling to walk/move last night (also improved - but not completely fixed - with meds) and they did a strep test which came back positive.The reason I'm really worried though is the weight loss and his medical record in general. I looked up his growth chart when I got home (I can access his records online) and he has grown 1.3 inches in the last 6 months but his weight dropped by 1 pound, causing his BMI to go from the 20th percentile to the 1st. I also looked at his blood work. They checked his hemoglobin at his 6-year checkup in July and that was low at 10, but they told me to just make sure he's eating iron (he eats a lot of iron-rich foods but doc said to just increase them). The last time he had a CBC was 5 years ago at his 1 year check-up but I looked at it anyway and his lymphocytes were high and neutrophils were low, but I don't think his doctor ever said anything about abnormal results so maybe that's not a concern? I didn't have online access at the time so I'm sure when they didn't call with results, I assumed they were normal.Should I have the doctor do a CBC if he keeps getting infections or not gaining weight/losing weight? Or should the doctor tell me if these things are concerning? I feel like a hypochondriac but I really just have a feeling something isn't right. :(

###Answer: Not likely to be something to stress over.Though it varies by your community/exposure risks, I have seen multiple cases between the hospital and clinic this last month with multiple viruses, back to back viruses, etc. It is not unreasonable that he was sick multiple times.The fever is likely from whatever viral processes he had going on.  Outside of strep nothing sounds bacterial from what youÛªve mentioned so I think 3 rounds of antibiotics was more appeasement or risk stratification than ÛÏappropriateÛ treatment.  Without a known or suspected bacterial nidus, no reason for antibiotics.He could have poorer dental hygiene with being sick, inflammation from infection, or it could be something like a vitamin C deficiency with the bleeding gums and recurrent infections.  Load him up with some emergenC.Weight loss is normal when being sick and I wouldnÛªt even look at his weight again until heÛªs been healthy for around 4-6 weeks with normal appetite.HFM is a clinical diagnosis, I wouldnÛªt send you to get the $800+ PCR test to confirm it in just about any case, since the management wouldnÛªt change.His CBC 5 years ago is has virtually no relevance to his current state unless there was a pathological anomaly like leukemia found on the initial one.  I wouldnÛªt even concern myself with mild anemia in 1-2 year olds at that level due to increased milk consumption and the body still ramping up production while growing rapidly.At the end of the day nothing here is concerning for him being sick beyond seasonal illness but you should speak to your pediatrician about it in more detail so you feel comfortable that youÛªve covered your bases if youÛªre truly still worried.<end_of_turn>

###Question: 45 F. 5'7", 220 lbs, former smoker. Drink occasionally. Nothing recreational. Meds: omeprazole daily, famotidine prn, cetirizine daily. I had an abdominal/pelvic CT today for months long issue of epigastric pain radiating to the back. Endoscopy was normal, symptoms not relieved by PPIs or H2 blockers, hence the CT.My question is regarding an incidental finding on the CT that the GI office did not bring up when they called me to discuss results. I only saw the complete report after getting off the phone.There was nothing on the CT that could explain my GI symptoms, but under the "Findings" section for lower chest "mild scarring/atelectasis" is listed. No other description is given. However, these findings are left out of the "Impressions" section of the report. As I said, I'm a former smoker. I have also had pneumonia at least 3 times in my life with a bout back in April. I didn't have a chest x-ray until May, a couple of weeks later, and that read "Impression: Peribronchial thickening consistent with bronchiolitis and/or reactive airway disease". No one called me to discuss those particular results and I had mostly recovered from the pneumonia (I thought) so I just shrugged it off. Turns out that since that bout of pneumonia, I have a harder time catching my breath than I used to and it's even a bit painful sometimes depending on the level of strain.The CT report is verbatim as follows:  "Lower chest: mild scarring/atelectasis" Can someone explain to me what this actually might mean for me clinically? Google U just screams "COLLAPSED LUNG" at me and that is not helpful. Is this something I need to be concerned about? What could be the cause? Can it be related to the findings on that x-ray? Should I get a pulmonology consult?I should add that I am changing insurance plans for the 2nd time in one year and the town I live in has a provider shortage and most of them are only accepting new OB patients. It has been difficult getting care because of this.Thanks for the input.

And here is the original response that needs to be more empathetic:

###Answer: Atelectasis isnÛªt an uncommon finding. It just means your lung in that area is not being inflated. It is indeed collapsed. This can be for any number of reason but for most it is due to lack of exercise or activity. ItÛªs also common in those with recurrent infections or get bronchitis because gunk builds up and blocks airways from getting proper aeration. Typically when you work your body, you tend to breath in harder which opens up all portions of your lungs. Your lungs are made up of tons of tiny little balloons (alveoli). The balloons at the bottom of your lung sometimes need extra force to really open them up. In your case, if you have scarring in that area, it may be even harder to inflate. Atelectasis is when the balloons collapse and havenÛªt been opened up in some time. It looks like your lung tissue has shrunken but typically isnÛªt a problem unless a large portion of your lung is affected. If youÛªve never tried one, a spirometer might be beneficial to help open up this portion of your lung. Guaifenesin to clear out mucus may also help. It can also be painful to open that portion of the lung up if atelectasis has been long standing.<end_of_turn>
